pattern_result.executive_summary: Ghostty has a critical bus factor crisis with Mitchell Hashimoto owning 80%+ of core modules, while review quality varies wildly by reviewer and context. The team has hidden experts making architect-level changes with minimal commits, and a concerning pattern of rubber-stamp reviews that prevent knowledge transfer.

insights.title: Single Point of Failure: Mitchell Controls Everything
insights.description: Mitchell Hashimoto has 81% ownership of src/terminal, 81% of macos/Sources, 84% of src/apprt, and 99% of src/inspector. If Mitchell becomes unavailable, the project effectively stops. The bus factor for these critical modules ranges from 0.06-0.09, which is catastrophically low.

insights.title: The Phantom Reviewer: 00-kat's Empty Approvals
insights.description: User 00-kat appears as a reviewer on multiple PRs but ONLY provides empty comments and rubber-stamp approvals. They reviewed PRs #10676, #10618, #10645, #10636, #10644 without a single substantive comment, suggesting they may be gaming review metrics.

insights.title: Hidden Renderer Expert: Qwerasd
insights.description: Qwerasd (qwerasd205@users.noreply.github.com) owns 63% of src/renderer despite only 71 total commits. They've made architect-level changes to the rendering pipeline but aren't recognized as a core maintainer. This person should be promoted to renderer module owner.

insights.title: Review Jekyll and Hyde: Inconsistent Quality by Same Reviewers
insights.description: pluiedev provides thorough architectural feedback on PR#10428 but rubber stamps PR#10328. jcollie gives thorough reviews on PR#10155 but rubber stamps PR#10455. This inconsistency suggests reviewers may be selectively engaged based on personal interest rather than code criticality.

insights.title: Cross-Module Bridge: Jeffrey Ollie
insights.description: Jeffrey C. Ollie (jeff@ocjtech.us) has 144 commits across src/apprt (12% ownership), src/terminal (8%), src/config (12%), making them the only significant cross-module contributor besides Mitchell. They should be leveraged for knowledge transfer between teams.

insights.title: One-Hit Wonder Architects
insights.description: Multiple contributors made single, architect-level PRs then disappeared: mauroporras (PR#9335 - word boundaries), ClearAspect (PR#9656 - shader injection), phaistonian (PR#9784 - color picker). These represent untapped expertise that could mentor others.

insights.title: Knowledge Transfer Failure: Teaching Reviews Are Rare
insights.description: Only 2 reviews out of 50+ analyzed actually transferred knowledge: jparise on PR#10455 (taught integrity checking) and flou on PR#10636 (explained French conventions). Most 'thorough' reviews catch bugs but don't explain why, preventing team growth.

insights.title: The Silent Line Changer: Daniel Wennberg
insights.description: Daniel Wennberg has only 64 commits but changed +17,451/-3,985 lines across terminal, renderer, and font modules. This 273:1 addition ratio suggests major feature implementations that aren't reflected in commit count. They're a hidden heavy contributor.

recommendations: Create module ownership teams: Assign Qwerasd as renderer lead, Jacob Sandlund as font lead
Implement mandatory cross-reviewer policy: PRs touching Mitchell's modules need 2 non-Mitchell reviews
Remove 00-kat from reviewer pool or require written feedback for approvals
Pair one-time architect contributors with regular maintainers for knowledge capture sessions
Create review templates that require 'why' explanations, not just 'what' is wrong
Fast-track Jeffrey Ollie to senior maintainer status for cross-module coordination
